The odd and even parts of the exponential function

Using the approach outlined above we see that the even part of \(e^x\) is \(\dfrac{1}{2}(e^x+e^{-x})\) and the odd part of \(e^x\) is \(\dfrac{1}{2}(e^x-e^{-x})\) We give these new functions special names: \(\cosh x\) (pronounced ‘cosh’ \(x\)) and \(\sinh x\) (pronounced ‘shine’ \(x\)). 

Key Point: Hyperbolic functions

\[\cosh x \equiv \dfrac{1}{2}(e^x+e^{-x})\]

\[\sinh x \equiv \dfrac{1}{2}(e^x-e^{-x})\]


These two functions, when added and subtracted, give \[\begin{align*} \cosh x+\sinh x &\equiv e^x, \\ \cosh x-\sinh x &\equiv e^{-x}.\end{align*}\] The graphs of \(\cosh x\) and \(\sinh x\) are shown in the below figure.

Note that \(\cosh x>0\) for all values of \(x\) and that \(\sinh x\) is zero only when \(x=0\).
